name: Union

types.name: Union
types.comment:
A set of strictly non-overlapping Intervals.

Opaque type; do not export.

values.name: fromInterval
values.comment: Construct a "union" from a single Interval.

values.name: fromIntervals
values.comment: Additively construct a union from an unordered list of arbitrary Intervals.

values.name: subtract
values.comment:
Subtract interval `b` from interval `a`, returning the parts of
`a` that did not intersect with `b`.

E.g.:

  - [1, 3) - (1, 2] = { {1}, (2, 3) }

values.name: subtractInterval
values.comment:
Subtract an interval from the given union, returning the contents of the
union that did not intersect with the interval.

E.g.:

  - { [1, 3), (5, 8] } - (1, 3) = { {1}, (5, 8] }

values.name: subtractUnions
values.comment:
Subtract union `b` from union `a`, returning the contents of `a` that
did not intersect with `b`.

E.g.:

  - { [1, 3), (5, 8] } - { (1, 3), [6, 7] } = { {1}, (5, 6), (7, 8] }

values.name: unionOfIntervals
unionToString
values.comment: Return the string representation of the given Union.

name: Interval

types.name: Bound
types.comment:
Represents an upper or lower, closed or open endpoint of an Interval.
This encompasses the "endpoints" of unbounded intervals when the bound value
is either of the `Infinity` values in the floating point spec.

Opaque type.

types.name: Interval
types.comment:
An interval over the reals. May be over either the Ordinary Reals `(-∞, +∞)` or
the Extended Reals `[-∞, +∞]`.
`Bounded x y` will always satisfy `x < y`. (`x == y` is either degenerate or empty)

Opaque type.

values.name: adjoins
values.comment:
Are these two intervals adjoins? I.e., do they share an upper-lower or
lower-upper bound, exactly one of which is closed, and do not intersect each other?

    let
        a = interval (includes 1) (excludes 3)  -- [1, 3)
        b = interval (includes 2) (includes 4)  -- [3, 4]
        c = interval (includes 3) (includes 4)  -- (3, 4]
        d = interval (includes 3) (includes 4)  -- [2, 3]
    in
        [ adjoins a b = True
        , adjoins a c = False
        , adjoins a d = False
        ]

values.name: closure
values.comment:
Returns the smallest closed interval containing a.

    -- `closure((x, y)) == [x, y]`
    interior (interval (excludes 0) (excludes 2)) == interval (includes 0) (includes 2)

values.name: degenerate
values.comment: A degenerate Interval.

values.name: empty
values.comment: An empty Interval.

values.name: excludes
values.comment: An exclusive endpoint of an interval.

values.name: hull
values.comment:
The convex hull of two intervals. This is similar to union in that
it includes all the points of the component intervals, and for
non-overlapping intervals, the points between them.

values.name: includes
values.comment: An inclusive endpoint of an interval.

values.name: interior
values.comment:
Returns the largest open interval contained within a.

    -- `interior([x, y]) == (x, y)`
    interior (interval (includes 0) (includes 2)) == interval (excludes 0) (excludes 2)

values.name: intersection
values.comment: The intersection of two intervals. If the intervals overlap, this is the common part. If not, this is the empty interval.

values.name: intersects
values.comment:
Do these two intervals intersect?

    let
        a = interval (includes 1) (excludes 3)
        b = interval (includes 2) (includes 4)
        c = interval (includes 3) (includes 4)
    in
        [ intersects a b = True
        , intersects a c = False
        ]

values.name: intersectsPoint
values.comment:
Does this interval contain the given point?

    let
        a = interval (includes 1) (excludes 3)
    in
        [ intersectsPoint a 0 = False
        , intersectsPoint a 1 = True
        , intersectsPoint a 3 = False
        ]

values.name: interval
values.comment: Constructs an `Interval` from two Bounds.

values.name: intervalToString
values.comment: Return a String representation of an Interval.

values.name: isBounded
values.comment: Does this interval have finite bounds?

values.name: isDegenerate
values.comment: Is this a degenerate (point-valued) interval?

values.name: isEmpty
values.comment: Is this an empty interval?

values.name: isLeftBounded
values.comment: Does this interval have a finite lower bound, and an infinite upper bound?

values.name: isLeftOpen
values.comment: Is the lower bound of this interval open?

values.name: isRightBounded
values.comment: Does this interval have a finite upper bound, and an infinite lower bound?

values.name: isRightOpen
values.comment: Is the upper bound of this interval open?

values.name: leftBounded
values.comment: Convenience function for a left-bounded Interval (from some n to +∞)

values.name: lowerBoundValue
values.comment: Extract the value of the lower bound of an Interval.

values.name: rightBounded
values.comment: Convenience function for a right-bounded Interval (from -∞ to some n)

values.name: subtract
values.comment:
Subtract interval `b` from interval `a`, returning a list of the parts of
`a` that did not intersect with `b`.

E.g.:

  - [1, 3) - (1, 2] = [ {1}, (2, 3) ]

values.name: unbounded
values.comment:
An unbounded Interval over the [Extended Reals.] `[-∞, +∞]`

[Extended Reals.]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interval_(mathematics)#Infinite_endpoints

values.name: upperBoundValue
values.comment: Extract the value of the upper bound of an Interval.
